channel.title: Virtual Reality - The Oculus Rift
channel.description:
I stumbled upon this little Kickstarter project that's been going on for a while now. You may have heard of it but I didn't see a thread on this so here you go: [url]https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1523379957/oculus-rift-step-into-the-game[/url]
So it's essentially a really cool Virtual Reality visor thing that's in development. Seems like it may be on of the first [i]true [/i]visors in development. What really got me interested (no surprise here) was the Gabe Newell and Michael Abrash both made an appearance in the video. Especially since Valve has seemed to be pretty big on wearable computing lately I don't think the two projects are related, but it's still pretty cool. Anyone feel like buying a dev kit just to toy with it?

item.title: Virtual Reality - The Oculus Rift
item.dc:creator: gibbelin
item.description:
Bloodshot:

Saw this earlier, seems interesting, but I’m still skeptical about using my head to turn in a game, as smooth as it may be with very low latency

It’s supposed to be implemented so that the mouse/controller moves your aim and view like normal, but you also get x amount of degrees on each axis (hopefully, including z) that are controlled by the Rift.

The rift doesn’t move the gun, but the view from the perspective of the player character.

item.title: Virtual Reality - The Oculus Rift
item.dc:creator: Dias
item.description:
I was just about to start this thread. Since it has both John Carmack’s & Gabe Newell’s approval, it certainly has my interest. Hell, it might be a day-one buy depending on the price.

Bloodshot:

Saw this earlier, seems interesting, but I’m still skeptical about using my head to turn in a game, as smooth as it may be with very low latency

I doubt that head-tracking will be the sole method of looking around. Not everybody has a wireless keyboard, wireless mouse & swivel chair to work with.

Edit: They should add stereoscopic cameras on the outside so it could be used for augmented reality.
